case_id: State of Rajasthan v. Om Prakash (2002)
facts: On 03.07.1986, in the afternoon, the deceased, a minor girl aged about 7 years, went out to graze goats in Village Dudu, Rajasthan.
When she did not return by evening, her family and villagers searched for her.
On 04.07.1986, in the morning, her dead body was found near a 'Nala' (drain/stream).
PW-3 (victim's father) lodged an FIR (No. 112/86) at Police Station Dudu.
An inquest report (Ex. P-3) was prepared.

Post-mortem examination was conducted by Dr. R.K. Goyal (PW-1), who found 11 external injuries (including incised wounds, abrasions, contusions) and signs consistent with rape (torn hymen, presence of whitish discharge). Cause of death opined as shock due to multiple injuries, sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, with possible asphyxia (throttling).
PW-2 (Mohan) stated he saw the accused Om Prakash taking the deceased girl towards the 'Nala' between 4-5 PM on 03.07.1986.
Accused Om Prakash was arrested on 07.07.1986.
Pursuant to a disclosure statement made by the accused under Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, a 'Kassi' (spade) was recovered from his house.

The Serologist report indicated human blood on the recovered Kassi and the accused's underwear, though the blood group was inconclusive. Semen was detected on vaginal swabs and the victim's 'Ghaghri' (skirt).
The Trial Court (Addl. Sessions Judge, Kishangarh) convicted the accused under Sections 302 and 376 IPC, sentencing him to death for murder and 10 years RI for rape.
The High Court of Rajasthan acquitted the accused, finding PW-2 unreliable, doubting the recovery evidence, and deeming medical evidence insufficient to connect the accused.
The State of Rajasthan filed an appeal against the acquittal in the Supreme Court.
ipc_sections: Section 300 (Murder - Definition, applied for conviction under S. 302)
Section 375 (Rape - Definition, applied for conviction under S. 376)
Section 27, Indian Evidence Act (How much of information received from accused may be proved - related to recovery of Kassi)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in disbelieving the testimony of the 'last seen' witness (PW-2), whose statement was credible and corroborated by other evidence.
precedents: State of U.P. v. Satish (2005) 3 SCC 114
Bodhraj @ Bodha v. State of J&K (2002) 8 SCC 45
State of U.P. v. Anil Singh AIR 1988 SC 1998
elements: Proximity in time between 'last seen' and discovery of body
Corroboration from medical evidence and recovery

counter_arguments.loophole: Potential delay or minor inconsistencies in PW-2's statement, which the High Court relied upon for acquittal.
supporting_precedents: Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra (1978) 4 SCC 371
Sahib Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1997 SC 2417
Balakrushna Swain v. State of Orissa (1971) 3 SCC 192

prosecution_arguments.argument: The recovery of the blood-stained Kassi at the instance of the accused under Section 27, Evidence Act, is a valid and incriminating piece of circumstantial evidence.
precedents: Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor AIR 1947 PC 67
State of Maharashtra v. Suresh (2000) 1 SCC 471
State of Punjab v. Baldev Singh (1999) 6 SCC 172
elements: Kassi linked to crime (human blood detected)

counter_arguments.loophole: Inconclusive blood grouping on the Kassi and the place of recovery potentially being accessible weakens the link.
supporting_precedents: Prabhoo v. State of U.P. AIR 1963 SC 1113
Surjit Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1994 SC 110
Santa Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1956 SC 526

prosecution_arguments.argument: The medical evidence conclusively establishes both rape and homicidal death, strongly corroborating the prosecution case built on PW-2's testimony and the recovery.
precedents: State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh (1996) 2 SCC 384
Mulakh Raj v. Satish Kumar (1992) 3 SCC 43
State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup AIR 1974 SC 1570
elements: Evidence of sexual assault (torn hymen, semen)
Nature and number of injuries indicating homicide

counter_arguments.loophole: Medical evidence confirms the crime (corpus delicti) but does not directly identify the perpetrator.
supporting_precedents: Mani v. State of Tamil Nadu (1994) SCC (Cri) 1621
Ashish Batham v. State of M.P. (2002) 7 SCC 317
Kehar Singh v. State (Delhi Admn.) AIR 1988 SC 1883

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court rightly acquitted as the 'last seen' evidence (PW-2) is unreliable due to inherent contradictions and delay in disclosure.
edge_cases: Standard of proof required for 'last seen' evidence, especially when it's the primary link.
Natural conduct of witness (failure to raise immediate alarm).
precedents: Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808
State of UP v. Sukhbasi AIR 1985 SC 1224
Jagraj Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 2000 SC 3596

defense_arguments.argument: The recovery under Section 27 is inadmissible or lacks weight as the place was accessible and the serological evidence is inconclusive, failing to establish a definite link.
edge_cases: Strict compliance required for Section 27 admissibility.
Impact of inconclusive forensic reports on circumstantial evidence.
precedents: Dudh Nath Pandey v. State of U.P. AIR 1981 SC 911
Mohd. Arif @ Ashfaq v. State (NCT of Delhi) (2011) 13 SCC 621 (Regarding scrutiny of recovery)
State of Karnataka v. David Razario (2002) 7 SCC 728

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution failed to establish a complete and unbroken chain of circumstantial evidence pointing unerringly to the guilt of the accused, leaving room for reasonable doubt.
edge_cases: Standard of proof in circumstantial evidence cases ('must be proved' vs 'may be proved').
Multiple possible hypotheses consistent with innocence.
precedents: Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116
Hanumant Govind Nargundkar v. State of M.P. AIR 1952 SC 343
Padala Veera Reddy v. State of A.P. AIR 1990 SC 79

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. High Court judgment of acquittal set aside. Trial Court judgment convicting the respondent Om Prakash under Sections 302 and 376 IPC restored. However, the sentence of death under Section 302 IPC was commuted to imprisonment for life. The sentence of 10 years RI under Section 376 IPC was maintained. Sentences ordered to run concurrently.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found the High Court's reasons for discarding PW-2's ('last seen' witness) testimony to be 'flimsy', 'perverse', and based on 'insignificant discrepancies'. PW-2's testimony was deemed reliable.
The recovery of the Kassi under Section 27 was held valid. The Court reasoned that inconclusiveness of blood group does not negate the finding of human blood, which is corroborative.
The medical evidence clearly established rape and brutal murder, corroborating the ocular testimony of PW-2 and the recovery.
The chain of circumstantial evidence ('last seen' testimony + medical evidence + recovery) was considered complete and pointing exclusively to the guilt of the accused.
The High Court was found to have interfered with the Trial Court's findings on 'untenable grounds' and by taking a 'manifestly unreasonable' view of the evidence.

Commutation of the death sentence to life imprisonment was justified based on the considerable lapse of time since the crime (1986) and subsequent legal proceedings, making execution inappropriate in the circumstances.
cited_cases: State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup AIR 1974 SC 1570
Pulukuri Kottaya v. Emperor AIR 1947 PC 67
Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Implicitly applied principle)
Bodhraj @ Bodha v. State of J&K (2002) 8 SCC 45 (Relevant context for 'last seen' evidence)
State of U.P. v. Suresh @ Ramji AIR 1982 SC 1076 (Distinguished)
